unlabelled_sentence: # # # # Contraindications # # # # Diagnostic CT examination with i.v. contrast : Absolute : * Renal transplant recipients Relative : * Significantly reduced eGFR ( eGFR < 45 mL / min ) * Diabetes mellitus, especially in case of significantly reduced eGFR and treatment with biguanides ( metformin ) such as Glucophage, Orabet or Avandamet * Multiple myeloma * Elevated P-uric acid * Thyrotoxicosis ( untreated ) * Myocardial infarction, acute or recent * Severe allergy, asthma * High fever * Treatment with nephrotoxica
* None
* Pregnancy
* Dehydration
* Dialysis
* Albuminuria

labels:
[
    ParentActivity(span="Investigation and referral"),
    Specification(span="vascular clinic"),
    Observation(span="Pseudoaneurysms"),
    Specification(span="are most common in the inguinal arteries"),
    Input(span="For sizes"),
    Guard(span="up to to 2 cm"),
    Observation(span="natural history is usually benign"),
    PurposeOutcome(span="most thromboses occur spontaneously"),
    Input(span="For sizes"),
    Guard(span="of 2 - 3 cm"),
    ActivityData(span="ultrasound-guided compression"),
    Activity(span="attempted"),
    Specification(span="the accumulation"),
    Specification(span="about 15 minutes"),
    ResponseEntity(span="be repeated"),
    Input(span="partial thrombosis"),
    Activity(span="done"),
    Specification(span="local hospital"),
    Actor(span="radiology staff"),
    Observation(span="inadequate treatment"),
    Observation(span="complicated pathoanatomy"),
    ConditionEntity(span="consider"),
    Specification(span="exposure of the artery"),
    Specification(span="sewing over the defect"),
]
unlabelled_sentence: * * Investigation and referral to vascular clinic Pseudoaneurysms are most common in the inguinal arteries. For sizes up to to 2 cm, the natural history is usually benign as most thromboses occur spontaneously. For sizes of 2 - 3 cm, ultrasound-guided compression can be attempted over the accumulation for about 15 minutes, which can be repeated in case of partial thrombosis. This can be done at the local hospital, often with the assistance of radiology staff. In cases with inadequate treatment or complicated pathoanatomy, consider endovascular coiling or open surgery with exposure of the artery and sewing over the defect.

Nurse's responsibilities
* Preparing the CRRT device for treatment
* Connecting the patient to the CRRT device
* Observation and care of patient with dialysis catheter
* Ordering CRRT blood samples according to instructions
* Documentation, observation and care of the patient during CRRT
* Cleaning of the CRRT device
* Following the CRRT checklist ( see appendix )
Physician's area of responsibility
* Establishes indication for CRRT and PrismaLung +, which is noted in the patient record
* Insertion of dialysis catheter
* Adjusting drug dosages
* Prescribing blood flow, fluid therapy and heparin
* Performing Best / Ord on CRRT samples

[

]
unlabelled_sentence: * * AB is selected according to resistance response * * * * Always check MIBA * *.
If culture is not available, older culture results can be used as a guide.
Start up
* tbl Pivmecillinam 400 mg x 3 dgl. or
* tbl.
Trimethroprim 200 mg x 2 dgl.
for unknown bacteriology.
Treatment is adjusted as soon as the result is known.
* * * * Always check MIBA for previous culture results regarding resistance patterns * * * *

If the standard prescription is Ampicillin 2g x 1 iv + Gentamicin 5mg / kg x 1 iv perop and resistance to Ampicillin has been seen in the past, give instead Piperacillin-tazobactam 4g x 1 iv + Gentamicin 5mg / kg x 1 iv perop.
If a patient is allergic to penicillin, cefuroxime 1500 mg x 1 iv + Gentamicin 5mg / kg x 1 iv perop
* If resistance to Piperacillin-tazobactam has also been seen previously, contact the back guard
* If resistance to Cefuroxime has been observed in penicillin-allergic patients, contact the back office.
If patients are admitted for preoperative antibiotic treatment, antibiotics are prescribed antibiotics from 14 : 00 the day before the procedure ( unless otherwise stated in the the medical record ).
The doses are as follows for normal GFR :
* * Ampicillin 2 g x 4 iv
* * Cefuroxime 1500 mg x 4 iv
* * Piperacillin-tazobactam 4 g x 4 iv
For transurethral procedures, supplemental Gentamycin is always given intraoperatively unless unless otherwise contraindicated.

There are many reasons why a child may need a tracheostomy tube, such as for example :
* Long-term ventilator treatment
* Congenital malformations
* Sequelae after long-term ventilator treatment
* Stenoses / malasias in the larynx / trachea
* Congenital recurrent paresis
* Viruses, edema, tumors, surgical procedures
* Swallowing problems / false swallowing
* Neck and facial trauma
